punctuation: The most common punctuation marks in English are: capital letters and full stops, question marks, commas, colons and semi-colons, exclamation marks and quotation marks.

syllable: In the word "engine", you should stress the first syllable.

plural: @ a word or form that expresses more than one.

collocation: @ A word or phrase that is often used with another word or phrase, in a way that sounds correct to people who have spoken the language all their lives, but might not be expected from the meaning.

article: & An article is usually news oriented, an essay can be literary.

laborer: @ A person who does unskilled physical work, especially outside.
But many employers skirted the law, preferring to hire less expensive laborers who crossed the border illegally.
sneaky: @ Doing things in a secret and unfair way.
Used to describe something you do, eat, or drink esp. when you do it without telling anyone or when you shouldn't really do it.
She snuck out for a sneaky cifarette.
There's always the temptation to take a sneaky peek at the presents under the Christmas tree.
receptor: @ A nerve ending that reacts to a change, such as heat or cold, in the body by sending a message to the central nervous system.
For example, mechanical receptors could assist in sensing water during drinking.
Compounds in cinnamon may activate enzymes that stimulate insulin receptors.
flee: @ To escape by running away, esp. because of danger or fear.
In order to escape capture, he fled to the mountains.
It's likely that the suspects have fled the country by now.
Every year thousands of people flee the big cities in search of the rural idyll.
War, famine and oppression have forced people in the region to flee from their homes.
inventory: @ A detailed list of all the things in a place.
A set of 24 gilded chairs appear on the inventory of the house for 1736.
@ The amount of goods a store has, or the value of them.
Our inventory of used cars is the best in town.
treat: @ To behave toward someone or deal with something in a particular way.
My parents treated us all the same when we were kids.
It's wrong to treat animals as if they had no feelings.
I treat remarks like that with the contempt that they deserve.
@ To use drugs, exercises, etc. to cure a person of a disease or heal an injury.
Western medicine tends to treat the symptoms and not the cause.
@ To buy or pay for something for another person.
I'm going to treat myself to (= buy for myself ) a new pair of sandals.
@ To put a special substance on material such as wood, cloth, metal, etc. or put it through a special process, in order to protect it from damage or decay.
The material has been treated with resin to make it waterproof.
@ A special and enjoyable occasion or experience.
We're going to Italy for the weekend - it's my birthday treat.
As a special treat, I'll take you to my favorite restaurant.
@ A type of food is eaten in addition to your usually meals, usually something sweet.
There is a lot of competition with the sugar-filled and artificially flavored treats on the store shelves.
Try to encourage children not to eat too many of those snacks and treats tha tend to pile on the pounds without provinding much nutrition.
@ A small piece of food, often specially produced, that is given to pets in addition to their usual food, for example as a reward.
The owner said the dog was dangerous, but when I fed it dog treats it would take them gently out of my hand.
unaided: @ According to the Oxford dictionary, unaided means ' without help from anyone or anything '
Microorganism is an organism that is too small to be seen by the unaided eye.
She reached the top of the mountain unaided.
deed: It seems to me that a lot of evil deeds are done in the name of religion.

in very deed: Her works are in very deed the echo of our times.

institute: @ An organization where people do a particular type of science, educational, or social work, or the buildings that it uses.
The institute derives all its money from foreign investments.
She is threatening to institute legal proceedings against the hospital.
